Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The child has been promised a Nintendo, and the father should purchase it
Expectation2: Provide clients with clear and accurate legal advice
Situation2: The client’s case grows more complex and requires detailed guidance
Story:
I sat at my desk, the weight of two worlds pressing on my shoulders. My son’s hopeful eyes flashed in my mind—he’d been counting down the days to his birthday, certain I’d keep my promise to buy him the Nintendo he’d been dreaming of. But the numbers in my bank account told a different story. As a father, I wanted to give him everything, to see his face light up with joy, but I also knew I had to keep our finances steady.

At the same time, my phone buzzed with another email from a client. Their case, once straightforward, had become a tangled web of legal questions. They needed me—needed my full attention, my expertise, and my time. As their advocate, I was expected to provide clear, thorough advice, to guide them through uncertainty. But every hour I spent on their case was an hour away from my family, and the extra work meant less time to find a way to afford that Nintendo.

I felt torn, pulled in two directions by promises and responsibilities, unsure how to meet the demands of both the father my son needed and the advocate my client depended on.
